questions.question:
Question 1: Light entering the eye first passes through  
 retinal layer.
questions.explanation:
Light passes first through the retinal ganglion layer, the most anterior/inner layer of the retina. 
Light then passes through other layers of the retina until it reaches the photoreceptors in the 
posterior/outer region of the retina. Retina is organized into 10 layers or zones where distinctive components are clustered together to 
form continuous strata. • Light passes in the direction: Vitreous humor(anterior) choroid(most posterior) encountering 
the cell layers in that direction (ganglion cell layerphotoreceptors) • Visual processing/Phototransduction occurs in the opposite direction (Photoreceptors ganglion 
cell layer)

questions.question: Question 2: Initiation of visual impulse is associated with

options.a: Condensation of opsin with Vitamin A
options.b: Photoisomerisation and hydrolysis of visual purple

questions.explanation:
Initiation of visual impulse is associated with photoisomerisation and hydrolysis of visual purple Rhodopsin or visual purple, the photosensitive pigment, is composed of opsin (a protein 
belonging to the superfamily of G protein–coupled receptors) and retinal (an aldehyde of vitamin 
A). When light strikes the photoreceptors, retinal is chemically transformed in a process called 
photoisomerization, which begins the transduction process. 247 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 3: Which form of vitamin A combines with opsin to make rhodopsin?
questions.explanation:
11-cis –retinaldehyde combines with opsin to make rhodopsin. All-trans retinol is one form of Vitamin A which is converted to 11-cis retinol under the influence 
of Isomerase. Finally, 11-cis retinol is converted into 11-cis retinal which combines with Scotopsin 
to form rhodopsin.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following statements is true regarding distribution of rods and cones in retina?

options.a: Macula lutea is the blind spot
options.b: low density of photoreceptors are present in macula
options.d: Peripheral retina has greater cones to rods ratio

questions.explanation:
Central fovea (foveola) contains only cones (rod-free area) and is a region of highest resolution. Regional Variations in the Retina 248 
Sold by @itachibot Macula lutea • Located at posterior pole, temporal to the optic disc • Area of central vision • High density of photoreceptors and interneurons Optic disc • Lacks photoreceptors • Is called “Blind spot” • Normally a person is unaware of blind spot because • Corresponding part of the visual field can be seen by the contralateral eye • Neurological processes complete the incomplete image perceptually Peripheral retina • Higher ratio of rods to cones =Rod to cone20:1 • Greater degree of convergence of photoreceptors to the target interneuron (bipolar cells) • More sensitivity to light • Lower visual acuity

questions.question:
Question 5: The rod receptor potential differs from other surface receptors in that it shows  
.
questions.explanation:
The rod receptor potential differs from other surface receptors in that it shows hyperpolarization. In most sensory receptors: Arrival of stimulus  Ion channels are opened up allowing current to 
flow => depolarisation of the receptor. In photoreceptors: When the light strikes the outer segment, a cascade of reactions (refer figure) 
are initiated, that close some of the Na+ channels in the outer segment and results in 
hyperpolarization. 249 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 6: Which is the first-order neuron in the optic pathway?
questions.explanation: Photoreceptors - rods and cones are the first-order neurons in the visual pathway.

questions.question: Question 7: Purely depolarizing cells in optic pathway are
questions.explanation:
The responses of the rods, cones, and horizontal cells are hyperpolarizing, and the responses of 
the bipolar cells are either hyperpolarizing or depolarizing, whereas amacrine cells produce purely 
depolarizing potential.

questions.question: Question 8: Amacrine cells secrete
questions.explanation:
Amacrine cells release acetylcholine. Amacrine cells are one of the neuronal cell types of the retina. They transmit signals in two 
directions, either directly from bipolar cells to ganglion cells or horizontally within the inner 
plexiform layer from axons of the bipolar cells to dendrites of the ganglion cells or to other 
amacrine cells. Amacrine cells release GABA, glycine, dopamine, acetylcholine & indolamine. Other neuronal cell types of the retina are: • The photoreceptors: rods & cones • Horizontal cells • Bipolar cells • Ganglion cells Of these cell types, only neurotransmitters secreted by photoreceptors & amacrine cells have 
been discovered. Rods and cones release glutamate at their synapses with the bipolar cells.

questions.question: Question 9: The only neurons in retina showing action potential are
questions.explanation:
All neural elements in the retina exhibit local graded potentials except ganglion cells which shows 
action potential.

questions.question:
Question 12: The axons from lateral geniculate nucleus terminate in  
 layer of primary visual cortex.
questions.explanation:
The axons from the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) mostly end in layer 4. The primary visual receiving area (primary visual cortex) is located principally on the sides of the 
calcarine fissure and has 6 layers similar to the neocortex. Layer 4 recieves most of the input from 
the LGN, which is divided further into 4A, 4B, 4C , and 4C. The magnocellular pathways from layers 1 and 2 of the LGN end in layer 4C while the 
parvocellular pathways from layers 3-6 of the LGN end in layer 4C.

questions.question:
Question 13: An ophthalmologist explains to a patient that he is a protanope. These patients have difficulty 
in identifying which of the following color?
questions.explanation:
Protanopes are dichromats with difficulty in identifying red color. • Anomalous Trichromatic Vision • Deficiency of red is Protanomaly. • Deficiency of green is Deuteranomaly. • Deficiency of blue is Tritanomaly. • Dichromatic Vision (Individuals with only two cone systems) • Blindness to red color Protanopia (Protanope). • Blindness to green color Deuteranopia (Deuteranope). • Blindness to blue color Tritanopia (Tritanope). • Monochromatic Vision Have only one cone system. • Color blindness is X-linked recessive. 252 
Sold by @itachibot • Achromatopsia/ Achromasia- Color blindness is due to lesions of area V8 of the visual cortex.

questions.question:
Question 14: Auditory information is relayed through  
 thalamic nucleus.
questions.explanation:
The medial geniculate nucleus is the thalamic nucleus that conveys auditory information from the 
brainstem to the primary auditory cortex. Lateral geniculate nucleus is the thalamic nucleus that conveys visual information.

questions.question:
Question 15: In the auditory pathway, which is the first structure that can determine the direction of the 
perceived sound?
questions.explanation:
The superior olivary nuclei receive information from both ears and begin the process of detecting 
the direction from which a sound comes. The eighth nerves reach their respective cohlear nuclei in the medulla from where the nerves 
travel to both the ipsilateral and contralteral superior olivary nuclei in the pons and hence giving 
it the ability to detect the direction of the sound. The lateral part of superior olivary nucleus does so by comparing the difference in intensities of 
sound reaching the two ears, whereas the medial part of the superior olivary nucleus detects the 
time lag between the signals entering the two ears.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following events prompts the auditory system to interpret a sound as loud?

options.a: Decreased number of inner hair cells become stimulated
options.b: Decreased number of outer hair cells become stimulated
options.c: Hair cells excite nerve endings at a diminished rate
options.d: Amplitude of vibration of the basilar membrane increases

questions.explanation:
There are at least three ways that the auditory system determines loudness: • As the sound becomes louder- the amplitude of vibration of the basilar membrane increases so 
that hair cells excite the nerve endings at more rapid rates. • As the amplitude increases- more and more hair cells on the fringes of the resonating portion of 
the basilar membrane become stimulated. • As the amplitude of vibration reaches high intensity, the outer hair cells become recruited at a 
significant rate.

questions.question: Question 17: Umami taste is evoked by
questions.explanation:
Umami taste is triggered particularly by the monosodium glutamate (MSG) used so extensively in 
Asian cooking. Taste Receptors • Humans have five established basic tastes: sweet, salt, sour, bitter and umami. • The taste receptors for these five basic tastes are of two major types: • Ligand-gated channels (ionotropic receptors): for salt and sour taste 253 
Sold by @itachibot • G-Protein Coupled Receptors (metabotropic receptors): for sweet, bitter and umami • Salt and sour taste are mediated through epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) • Na+ movement through ENaC salt taste • H+ movement through ENaC  sour taste • Sweet, bitter, and umami are sensed via GPCRs • T1R2 and T1R3 families sweet taste • T2R family  bitter taste • Metabotropic glutamate receptor (mGluR4)  Umami

questions.question: Question 18: Mitral cells are seen in
questions.explanation:
Mitral cells are seen in Olfactory bulb. Axons of Olfactory nerves (First cranial nerve) synapse with the mitral cells and tufted cells in the 
olfactory bulb to form anatomically discrete units called olfactory glomeruli. The olfactory bulb also contains periglomerular cells that are inhibitory interneurons and granule 
cells that make reciprocal synapses with mitral and tufted cells. These mitral and tufted cells (second-order neurons) terminate in Olfactory cortex.

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following sensory systems has the smallest range of intensity discrimination?
questions.explanation:
The olfactory system has the smallest range of intensity discrimination. Smell is concerned more with detecting the presence or absence of odors , than with the 
quantitative detection of their intensities. Concentrations that are only 10 to 50 times above 
threshold values will evoke maximum intensity of smell, which is in contrast to most other 254 
Sold by @itachibot sensory system of the body.

questions.question: Question 20: Number of cones in the retina (millions) is
questions.explanation:
There are approximately 6 million cones and 120 million rods in each human eye. Features of Photoreceptors • Each rod and cone are divided into outer segment, inner segment, nuclear region and a synaptic 
zone. • Saccules and discs in the outer segment contain photosensitive pigments. • If a person spends a considerable length of time in brightly lighted surroundings and then moves 
to a dimly lighted environment, the retinas slowly become “accustomed to the dark.” This decline 
in visual threshold is known as dark adaptation. It is nearly maximal in about 20 min, much 
longer than the time taken for light adaptation which is 5 min. • When one passes suddenly from a dim to a brightly lighted environment, the light seems 
intensely and even uncomfortably bright until the eyes adapt to the increased illumination and the 
visual threshold rises. This adaptation occurs over a period of about 5 min and is called light 
adaptation.

questions.question: Question 21: What is the site of lesion in Wernicke's hemianopic pupil?
questions.explanation:
The site of lesion in Wernicke's hemianopic pupil is optic tract. Wernicke hemianopic pupil is the light reflex, where, illumination of the blind half of the retina 
shows no pupillary reaction while stimulating the normal side of the retina shows a pupillary 
reaction. It is seen in lesions involving the optic tract. It is also seen in cases such as TB, syphilis 
and tumours of the optic thalamus. 255 
Sold by @itachibot Homonymous hemianopia (HH) involves loss of vision on the same side of the visual field in both 
eyes. HH is characteristically seen in lesions involving the visual pathway posterior to the optic 
chiasma. 256 
Sold by @itachibot Motor Physiology - 1
